anchor.surface_text: In Laxmanappa Hanumantappa Jamkhandi v. The Union of India Another 1 , this Court held that as there is a special provision in Art. 265 of the Constitution that no tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law, cl. 1 of Art. 31 must be regarded as concerned with deprivation of property otherwise than by imposition or collection of tax

concepts.interpretation: Concerned with deprivation of property otherwise than by tax.

issues.text: under what circumstances does the dismissal of a writ petition under Art. 226 by the High Court create a bar of res judicata to a subsequent petition under Art. 32

anchor.surface_text: We hold that if a writ petition filed by a party under Art. 226 is considered on the merits as contested matter, and is dismissed the decision thus pronounced would continue to bind the parties unless it is otherwise modified or reversed by appeal

arguments.claim: The dismissal of a writ petition filed under Art. 226 creates a bar of res judicata against a similar petition filed under Art. 32 on the same or similar facts and praying for the same or similar writ.

anchor.surface_text: The opponents in all these petitions have raised a preliminary objection against the maintainability of the writ petitions on the ground that in each case the petitioners had moved the High Court for a similar writ under Art. 226 and the High Court has rejected the said petitions. The argument is that the dismissal of a writ petition filed by a party for obtaining an appropriate writ creates a bar of res judicata against a similar petition filed in this Court under Art. 32 on the same or similar facts and praying for the same or similar writ.

arguments.court_reasoning: If a writ petition under Art. 226 is considered on merits as contested matter and dismissed, it binds unless modified or reversed.

arguments.claim: The principle of res judicata is no more than a technical rule similar to the rule of estoppel and cannot be pleaded against a petition seeking to enforce fundamental rights under Art. 32.

arguments.claim: Granting relief under Art. 32 is discretionary like under Art. 226, even if fundamental right proved.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it is urged by the learned Advocate-General of Punjab, who led the respondents, that Art. 32 1  does not guarantee to every citizen the right to make a petition under the said article but it merely gives him the right to move this Court by appropriate proceedings, and he contends that the appropriate proceedings in cases like the present would be proceedings by way of an application for special leave under Art. 136 ... In support of the argument that it is in the discretion of this Court to grant an appropriate relief or refuse to do so reliance has been placed on the observations made in two reported decisions of this Court.

arguments.claim: Rule of res judicata based on public policy and finality of judgments, applies even to Art. 32 petitions.

anchor.surface_text: But, is the rule of res judicata merely a technical rule or is it based on high public policy? arguments.claim: Dismissal in limine or for laches/alternative remedy under Art. 226 does not create res judicata bar to Art. 32.

arguments.claim: Dismissal in limine without speaking order does not create res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: If the petition is dismissed in limine without passing a speaking order then such dismissal cannot be treated as creating a bar of res judicata. It is true that, prima facie, dismissal in limine even without passing a speaking order in that behalf may strongly suggest that the Court took the view that there was no substance in the petition at all but in the absence of a speaking order it would not be easy to decide what factors weighed...

Accordingly we must hold that the said order does not create a bar of res judicata...

holdings.text: The dismissal of a writ petition under Article 226 by a High Court on merits after contest creates a bar of res judicata to a subsequent petition under Article 32 on the same facts and for similar relief.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Res judicata embodies public policy for finality of judgments by competent courts; applies to writ jurisdictions which are concurrent; prior decisions like Sharma support application to Art.32.

holdings.text: Article 32 confers a guaranteed fundamental right to move the Supreme Court by original petition for enforcement of fundamental rights, not merely by appropriate proceedings like special leave under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that Art. 32 does not confer upon a citizen the right to move this Court by an original petition but merely gives him the right to move this Court by an appropriate proceeding according to the nature of the case seems to us to be unsound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of 'appropriate proceedings' refers to nature of writ, not type of proceeding; Romesh Thapar confirms SC as protector of fundamental rights.

holdings.text: The rule of res judicata is based on high public policy essential to the rule of law, not merely a technical rule like estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: But, is the rule of res judicata merely a technical rule or is it based on high public policy? If the rule of res judicata itself embodies a principle of public policy which in turn is an essential part of the rule of law then the objection that the rul

holdings.reasoning_summary: Foundation in public interest for finality (interest rei publicae ut sit finis litium) and avoiding vexation (nemo debet bis vexari); distinguished from equity-based estoppel; S.11 CPC embodies policy.

holdings.text: A judgment of a High Court under Article 226 creates res judicata for Article 32 petition as jurisdictions are concurrent and competent for the cause.

anchor.surface_text: The next question to consider is whether it makes any difference to the application of this rule that the decision on which the plea of res judicata is raised is a decision not of this Court but of a High Court exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.11 CPC competence satisfied; same scope of writs, same cause (fundamental right infringement); no distinction between courts.

holdings.text: Remedies under Articles 226 and 32 are not alternate such that pursuing one precludes the other by res judicata if decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: There is one more argument Which still remains to be considered. It is urged that the remedies available to the petitioners to move the High Court under Art. 226 and this Court under Art. 32 are alternate remedies and so the adoption of one remedy

holdings.reasoning_summary: If merits contested and decided, binds parties; cannot bypass by Art.32; Gulab Koer distinguished as remedies not parallel.

holdings.text: Dismissal of Article 226 petition in limine without speaking order does not create res judicata bar to Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: If the petition is dismissed in limine without passing a speaking order then such dismissal cannot be treated as creating a bar of res judicata. It is true that, prima facie, dismissal in limine even without passing a speaking order in that behalf

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of speaking order prevents determining if on merits; prima facie suggests no substance but unsafe to assume bar.

holdings.text: Dismissal of Article 226 petition for laches or alternative remedy does not bar Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: If the petition filed in the High Court under Art. 226 is dismissed not on the merits but because of the laches of the party applying for the writ or because it is held that the party had an alternative remedy available to it, then the dismissal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary grounds under 226 differ from entitlement under 32 as fundamental right; facts may be relevant under 32 but not bar.

holdings.text: Withdrawal of Article 226 petition does not create res judicata.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No decision on merits; express observation merits not considered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allahabad HC dismissed on merits after argument in light of Full Bench; same grounds.

holdings.text: Writ Petition No. 5 of 1958 is barred by res judicata and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the decision of the High Court pronounced by it on the merits of the petitioners writ petition under Art. 226 is a bar to the making of the present petition, under Art. 32. In the result this writ petition fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bombay HC rejected contentions on merits against same statute; form of grounds substantially same.

holdings.text: Writ Petition No. 8 of 1960 not barred; preliminary objection rejected; set down for Constitution Bench.

precedents.cited_proposition: citizen entitled to relief under Art. 32 if fundamental rights violated, waiver not applicable

precedents.citation: Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: It is because of this aspect of the matter that in Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras 1 , in the very first year after the Constitution came into force,

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court must entertain Art. 32 petitions as protector of fundamental rights, cannot refuse on ground of approaching HC first
precedents.cited_holding: this Court thus constituted the protector and guarantor of the fundamental rights, and it cannot, consistently with the responsibility so laid upon it, refuse to entertain applications seeking protection against infringements of such rights

anchor.surface_text: In considering the essential elements of res judicata one inevitably harks back to the judgment of Sir William de Grey, afterwards Lord Walsingham in the leading Duchess of Kingstons case 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: judgment of court of concurrent jurisdiction directly on point is conclusive as bar or evidence between same parties
precedents.cited_holding: the judgment of a court of concurrent jurisdiction, directly upon the point, is as a plea, a bar, or as evidence, conclusive between the same parties, upon the same matter, directly in question in another court

precedents.citation: Pandit M. S. M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha 3

anchor.surface_text: This Court had occasion to consider the application of the rule of res judicata to a petition filed under Art. 32 in Pandit M. S. M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha 3 .

precedents.case_name: Pandit M. S. M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha
precedents.cited_proposition: res judicata applies to bar second Art. 32 petition on same facts after dismissal of first Art. 32 petition
precedents.cited_holding: the question determined by the previous decision of this Court cannot be reopened in the present case and must govern the rights and obligations of the parties which are substantially the same

precedents.citation: Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this decision Sinha, C. J., who spoke for the Court, referred to the earlier decision of this Court in Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen 1 and observed

precedents.case_name: Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen
precedents.cited_proposition: principle of res judicata applies even if first tribunal lacked jurisdiction for subsequent suit or subject-matter not exactly same

precedents.citation: Janardan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad 2

anchor.surface_text: We may at this stage refer to some of the earlier decisions of this Court where the present problem was posed but not finally or definitely answered. In Janardan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad 2 ,

precedents.case_name: Janardan Reddy v. State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: question of Art. 32 after Art. 226 dismissal reserved
precedents.cited_holding: we have not considered it necessary to decide whether an application under Art. 32 is maintainable after a similar application under Art. 226 is dismissed by the High Court, and we reserve our opinion on that question

precedents.citation: Syed Qasim Razvi v. The State of Hyderabad 1

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect are the observations made by Mukherjea, J., as he then was, in Syed Qasim Razvi v. The State of Hyderabad 1 . On the other hand,

precedents.case_name: Syed Qasim Razvi v. State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: question of Art. 32 after Art. 226 dismissal reserved

precedents.citation: Bhagubhai Dullabhabhai Bhandari v. The District Magistrate, Thana 2

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, in Bhagubhai Dullabhabhai Bhandari v. The District Magistrate, Thana 2 the decision of the High Court was treated as binding between the parties

precedents.case_name: Bhagubhai Dullabhabhai Bhandari v. District Magistrate, Thana
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court decision binding if special leave refused
precedents.cited_holding: but that is a closed chapter so far as the Courts including this Court also are concerned inasmuch as the petitioners conviction stands confirmed

anchor.surface_text: it has not been held in England in Re, Hastings No. 2 1 that an applicant for a writ of habeas corpus in a criminal matter who has once been heard by a Divisional

precedents.cited_proposition: successive habeas corpus applications to different Divisional Courts barred
precedents.cited_holding: an applicant for a writ of habeas corpus... is not entitled to be heard a second time by another Divisional Court

anchor.surface_text: The said decision has been subsequently applied in Re Hastings No. 3 1 to a writ petition filed for habeas corpus in a Divisional Court of the Chancery Division.

precedents.cited_proposition: Re Hastings (No.2) applied to Chancery Division habeas petition

precedents.citation: Mussammat Gulab Koer v. Badshah Bahadur 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention reliance has been placed on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Mussammat Gulab Koer v. Badshah Bahadur 1 . In that case

precedents.case_name: Mussammat Gulab Koer v. Badshah Bahadur
precedents.cited_proposition: adoption of one alternate remedy does not bar the other by res judicata
precedents.cited_holding: the two remedies though co-existing were not inconsistent so that when a party aggrieved has had recourse first to one remedy it cannot be precluded from subsequently taking recourse to the other

anchor.surface_text: In Petition No. 66 of 1956 we have already seen that the petition filed in the High Court was on the same allegations and was for the same relief The petitioners had moved the High Court to obtain a writ of certiorari to quash the decision of the Revenue Board against them, and when the matter was argued before the High Court in view of the previous decisions of the High Court their learned counsel did number press the petition. In other words, the points of law raised by the petition were dismissed on the merits. That being so, it is a clear case where the writ petition has been dismissed on the merits, and so the dismissal of the writ petition creates a bar against the competence of the present petition under Art. 32. The position with regard to the companion petition, No. 67 of 1956, is exactly the same. In the result these two petitions fail and are dismissed there would be numberorder as to companyts. In Writ Petition No. 8 of 1960 the position is substantially different. The previous petition for a writ filed by the petitioner No. 68 of 1952 in the Allahabad High Court was withdrawn by his learned companynsel and the High Court therefore dismissed the said petition with the express observation that the merits had number been companysidered by the High Court in dismissing it and so numberorder is to companyts was passed. This order the writ petition withdrawn which was passed on February 3, 1955, cannot therefore support the plea of res judicata against the present petition.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ Petitions Nos. 66 & 67 of 1956 and No. 5 of 1958 dismissed on grounds of res judicata from High Court writ dismissal on merits. Writ Petitions Nos. 8 of 1960, 77 of 1957 and 15 of 1957 not barred and set down for hearing on merits before Constitution Bench.
directions: For W.P. No. 77 of 1957: Petitioner to file the two orders of dismissal passed by the Punjab High Court.
W.P. No. 8 of 1960, W.P. No. 77 of 1957 and W.P. No. 15 of 1957 to be placed for hearing before Constitution Bench.

anchor.surface_text: In Petition No. 66 of 1956 we have already seen that the petition filed in the High Court was on the same allegations and was for the same relief The petitioners had moved the High Court to obtain a writ of certiorari to quash the decision of the Revenue Board against them, and when the matter was argued before the High Court in view of the previous decisions of the High Court their learned counsel did number press the petition. In other words, the points of law raised by the petition were dismissed on the merits. That being so, it is a clear case where the writ petition has been dismissed on the merits, and so the dismissal of the writ petition creates a bar against the competence of the present petition under Art. 32. The position with regard to the companion petition, No. 67 of 1956, is exactly the same. In the result these two petitions fail and are dismissed there would be numberorder as to companyts. In Writ Petition No. 8 of 1960 the position is substantially different. The previous petition for a writ filed by the petitioner No. 68 of 1952 in the Allahabad High Court was withdrawn by his learned companynsel and the High Court therefore dismissed the said petition with the express observation that the merits had number been companysidered by the High Court in dismissing it and so numberorder is to companyts was passed. This order the writ petition withdrawn which was passed on February 3, 1955, cannot therefore support the plea of res judicata against the present petition.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that Art. 32 does not confer upon a citizen the right to move this Court by an original petition but merely gives him the right to move this Court by an appropriate proceeding according to the nature of the case seems to us to be unsound.

That being so, it is a clear case where the writ petition has been dismissed on the merits, and so the dismissal of the writ petition creates a bar against the competence of the present petition under Art. 32. In Writ Petition No. 8 of 1960 the position is substantially different. The previous petition for a writ filed by the petitioner No. 68 of 1952 in the Allahabad High Court was withdrawn by his learned companynsel and the High Court therefore dismissed the said petition with the express observation that the merits had number been companysidered by the High Court in dismissing it and so numberorder is to companyts was passed. This order the writ petition withdrawn which was passed on February 3, 1955, cannot therefore support the plea of res judicata against the present petition.
